text:
MERRILL FERNANDO: If there
are established challenges

facing a man trying
to develop a brand,

create his own brand, I
faced them all and much,

much more because
if I had the backing

of my country and the trade,
it would have been easy.

Here I am fighting and trying
to explain to them that this

is necessity for us for
the long-term interest,

it is necessary to
have our own brands.

Why are we creating
brands outside our country

and letting them
take our money away?

But nobody was willing
to invest money,

and they didn't
depreciate my point.
They said, "We can't do that."
I said, "We can."

Nobody followed me, so
everywhere I had negatives.

Therefore, I knew if I had a
brand in a degrowing country,

I would have a great
story to tell you

about the farmers bringing their
crop direct to the markets,

and we had completely
different traders.

But you know my greatest
asset was that I knew nothing
about the market.

I knew I had a great product,
it had to be really unique.

Unique because I decided to add
full value right at the root.
So that would be a great story.
"I'm a farmer.

I grow my tea, package
it fresh at source

so that all the antioxidants
are packed fresh
for your enjoyment."

I had all those ideas coming ,
but they cost a lot of money.
So I did it in my own way.

I started with
two machines, then
I had to operate the machines.

Somehow, we managed
the initial stages

because we had no
brands in our country,
so there is no track record.

And the struggles I had
in printing a label,

designing, we didn't
have graphic artists,

nothing, so we had
to actually create.

I had to draw my own brand,
and create every little thing.

And because I didn't seek
assistance from experts,

I created my your way of
marketing origin-owned brand.

Now, if our own country
followed the example of Dilmah,

if 10 people followed,
our tea prices

would be twice where
they are, but nobody
is willing to invest.
